text: Jimi Hendrix hit the London scene like a
bomb every band every guitarist wanted
to see him we went down to the Scotch
and everyone was standing perfectly
still listening to this guy I'd never
seen anyone quite like him but he called
me over to sit next to him and he said I
think you're beautiful I thought that's
corny
but it worked
he'd never crossed the road in England
before and he'd only arrived that
morning and I looked to see if there was
taxi coming and Jimmy looked the
opposite direction coming from America
stepped out and nearly got run over I
grabbed him by the back of his jacket
just in time to pull him back otherwise
there wouldn't have been any Jimi
Hendrix he would have been squashed
there and then that's that night but the
hotel we talked all night it was just a
very gentle sort of person we suddenly
became boyfriend and girlfriend and it
stayed like that for two and a half
years it wasn't exactly glamorous in
those early days we stayed in a lot we
played games we played Monopoly we
played risk we used to jokingly call
each other by our middle names Jimmy was
Marshall and I was Mary the wind cries
Mary came about after Jimmy and I had a
row over my mashed potatoes they were
all lumpy and he complained and I took
great offense at this and I stormed out
and he followed me to the traffic light
so I got into a taxi and off I went
and when I got back he's actually
written the wind cries Mary all in one
sitting overnight and that was about the
about the round
the change came around late 68 when you
had all these hangers on and I went to
United States and this guy came around
and he put a bag down on the floor and
the bag gaped open and there was white
powder in it right on the top such a gun
silver colored handgun and I think that
was the breaking point I saw that and I
wanted to go home the Thursday afternoon
he died on the Friday morning I saw him
in Kensington Market and he seemed fine
he came up to me and squeezed me around
the waist and said oh I'm staying at the
Cumberland Hotel do you want to come
over for a drink later and in fact I
didn't go my friend called me up she
said Jimmy's dead I've just heard it on
the radio
according to her I didn't say anything I
put the phone down I didn't say a word
I'd tuned into the radio and they were
beginning to report it
Hendriks dead at 27 I was really upset I
still remember it now he did cross my
mind that had I gone round there it
might not have happened if only I'd have
done this if only there's no point in
dwelling on that I didn't go and it
happened
I've never visited the grave because I
prefer to remember him as he was
you
